author: By Adam Sella
title: Released hostages give Tel Aviv protesters hope for those left behind.
description: Hostages who were recently released thanked demonstrators for continuing to pressure their government.
content: Yelena Trupanob, 50, a Russian Israeli hostage who was released from captivity in Gaza three days ago, had a message for the thousands of demonstrators who gathered in Tel Aviv on Saturday night to continue to pressure the Israeli government to make freeing the remaining hostages a top priority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: Sandra O’Connor’s Extraordinary Final Chapter
description: The Supreme Court justice found herself balancing conflicting demands of professional achievement and family expectations to the end.
content: Sandra Day O’Connor gave up lifetime tenure on the Supreme Court — a job she loved and one with extraordinary power — to care for her husband of 52 years as he deteriorated from dementia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 2, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 2, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about how complicated it can be for American presidents to balance their relationships with foreign allies misstated the title of Narendra Modi, the leader of India. He is the prime minister, not the president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Julianna Margulies Apologizes After Remarks on Black Support of Jews
description: The actress had said on a podcast that some Black people not standing with Jews after the Hamas attacks had been “brainwashed to hate Jews.”
content: The actress Julianna Margulies, who drew criticism this week after saying on a podcast that some Black people not standing with Jews after the recent attack by Hamas had been “brainwashed to hate Jews,” said on Friday that she “did not intend for my words to sow further division, for which I am sincerely apologetic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Crossing the Dnipro: What a Ukrainian Military Operation Might Mean
description: Ukrainian troops have taken positions on the east bank of the Dnipro River, posing a threat to Russia’s dominance of the region. Here is a look at the battlefield and the strategic implications.
content: Bands of Ukrainian soldiers fighting to take back territory on the eastern bank of the Dnipro River, an area long controlled by Russia, have been bombed by Russian warplanes, assaulted by Russian infantry and stalked by drones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A Mother Can Finally Breathe After the Pandemic
description: Access to mental health care made the difference.
content: When Yaneth Flores first moved to Albany, in upstate New York, in 2008, she needed some time to get used to the sleepiness of a small city. She had been working at a fish market near Boston, where she lived after fleeing violence and a bleak economy in El Salvador. She met her husband in Albany and eventually settled into life there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Henri Lopes, 86, Who Straddled Literature and Politics in Africa, Dies
description: His lauded fiction satirized abuses of power in the continent, but as a high official for the Republic of Congo, he benefited from a much-criticized government.
content: Henri Lopes, a writer and former prime minister of the Republic of Congo whose pioneering fiction mocked the abuses of African leaders but who later served one of the continent’s most brutal, died on Nov. 2 in the Paris suburb of Suresnes. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden Administration Unleashes Powerful Regulatory Tool Aimed at Climate
description: Its new estimate of the economic impact of climate change could create the legal justification for aggressive new regulations.
content: The Biden administration’s crackdown on methane leaks from oil wells is based in part on a new powerful policy tool that could strengthen its legal authority to cut greenhouse gas emissions across the entire economy — including from cars, power plants, factories and oil refineries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix Builds a ‘Squid Game’ Universe as It Awaits a Second Season
description: A reality show and a live experience are two ways of keeping the dystopian series in the public eye. Is the original’s bleak message being diluted?
content: On the same soundstage where Bob Barker lorded over “The Price Is Right,” “Squid Game” is coming to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Sullivan
title: All Things in Moderation, Especially When They’re Toxic
description: In “Most Delicious Poison,” Noah Whiteman explores nature’s fine line between killing and curing.
content: What doesn’t kill you might make you stronger. When it comes to nature’s toxins, they might even save your life (or at least blunt the sting of its finality). The distinction, as the evolutionary biologist Noah Whiteman explores in “Most Delicious Poison,” is all in the dosage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: George Santos Reveals One Truth: It’s Easy to Abuse Campaign Finance Laws
description: The newly ousted congressman, while an extreme case, illustrated the weaknesses of a system that relies on politicians to report their finances in good faith.
content: Perhaps no federal officeholder in modern American history has been accused of ignoring, testing or breaking as many aspects of campaign finance law so flagrantly, in such a short span of time, as George Santos has.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefano Montali
title: Christopher Paolini Wanted a Job Involving Dragons, So He Created One
description: Paolini, a best-selling author of young adult fantasy novels, has a new book out, “Murtagh.” In it, he returns to the world of “Eragon” and the adventures he began creating as a teenager.
content: In the months before Christopher Paolini wrote the book that made him a star in young adult fantasy, he built a hobbit hole. He’d been home-schooled, and by the time he turned 15 he’d already graduated from high school and read many of the classics — Leo Tolstoy, Alexandre Dumas and Jane Austen among them. So, in his family’s backyard near the banks of the Yellowstone River in Paradise Valley, Mont., he dug a 10-foot hole and converted a massive satellite dish into a makeshift roof. Elaborate plans for a Viking-style mead hall danced through his head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Henry Kissinger, Social Fixture
description: After leaving the White House, he returned to New York and became an in-demand guest, hitting the party circuit with the likes of Elizabeth Taylor and Madonna.
content: Henry A. Kissinger, the powerful diplomat who was awarded a Nobel Peace Prize and accused of being a war criminal for his realpolitik approach to foreign affairs, had a kind of second career on the society circuit, especially in the years after he served as secretary of state under Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Tim Dorsey, Who Turned Florida’s Quirks Into Comic Gold, Dies at 62
description: Long before Florida Man became a meme, he mined the Sunshine State’s weirdness for enough material to fill 26 darkly funny crime novels.
content: Tim Dorsey, who drew on his years as a crime reporter to fuel a second career writing a long series of darkly comic thrillers set along the back roads and back alleys of Florida’s weird, wild underbelly, died on Sunday at his home in Islamorada, a town in the Florida Keys. He was 62.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Vik Jolly
title: Man Suspected of Killing 3 Homeless Men in Los Angeles Is Arrested
description: Officials believe the man also killed a fourth person in San Dimas, Calif., after following the victim home. The killings happened within four days, authorities said.
content: Authorities have identified and arrested a suspect in connection with the killings of three homeless men in Los Angeles this week and tied the suspect to a fourth homicide nearby, officials said on Saturday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody Rosen
title: Behind the Scenes of the Most Spectacular Show On TV
description: Months of preparation, hundreds of staff, convoys of cutting-edge gear: inside the machine that crafts prime time’s most popular entertainment.
content: Arrowhead Stadium, the home of the Kansas City Chiefs, the N.F.L.’s defending champions, is a very loud place. Players say that when the noise reaches top volume, they can feel vibrations in their bones. During a 2014 game, a sound meter captured a decibel reading equivalent to a jet’s taking off, earning a Guinness World Record for “Loudest crowd roar at a sports stadium.” Chiefs fans know how to weaponize noise, quieting to a churchlike hush when the team’s great quarterback, Patrick Mahomes, calls signals but then, when opponents have the ball, unleashing a howl that can even drown out the sound of the play call crackling through the speaker inside the rival quarterback’s helmet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By S. Kirk Walsh
title: A Complicated Return for a Prodigal Daughter
description: In “Welcome Home, Stranger,” Kate Christensen takes readers inside the best kind of fictional family: a dysfunctional one.
content: In the first sentence of Kate Christensen’s unflinching eighth novel, “Welcome Home, Stranger,” the reader learns that Rachel Calloway’s mother has died — and she does what most people do when a parent passes away: “You get on a plane and go home.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: A protester self-immolates outside the Israeli Consulate in Atlanta.
description: A security guard tried to intervene but was unsuccessful, officials said.
content: A protester self-immolated on Friday afternoon outside of the Israeli Consulate building in Atlanta, in what the police described as “likely an extreme act of political protest.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Agnes Callard
title: I Teach the Humanities, and I Still Don’t Know What Their Value Is
description: This seems to be true of a lot of us.
content: If a group of math students fails to learn the material, that might be because the teacher is not trying hard enough or because she has been inappropriately tasked with, for example, teaching calculus to toddlers. Supposing, however, that neither of these things is true — the teacher is passionately invested in teaching, and she has many suitable students — yet her students all fail the final exam, eventually we would be forced to say that she might not know math so well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration Announces Rule to Cut Millions of Tons of Methane Emissions
description: The measure, which requires oil and gas producers to detect and fix leaks of the greenhouse gas, came as the U.S. vice president spoke at the COP28 climate summit.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris pledged at a United Nations climate summit on Saturday that the United States would spend billions more to help developing nations fight and adapt to climate change, telling world leaders that “we must do more” to limit global temperature rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: World Food Program Staff Confronts Cindy McCain Over Gaza Crisis
description: Staff members accused Ms. McCain, the W.F.P.’s leader, of not leveraging her position to speak out against the suffering of Palestinian civilians, and some have called for her removal.
content: As the truce in the Israel-Hamas war was ending on Thursday, Cindy McCain, the executive director of the United Nations’ World Food Program, met virtually with her staff to address an internal uproar over accusations that she was not leveraging her position to speak out against the suffering of Palestinian civilians in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: For Christina Hendricks, Beauty Comes Down to Corsets and Molding
description: “If it’s a piece of furniture that looks like it could run away — it might have legs or hands — I probably want it,” said the actress, whose series “The Buccaneers” suits her vintage proclivities.
content: After four seasons on the NBC crime caper “Good Girls,” Christina Hendricks was done with digging through trash bins and having guns held to her head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: How a Suspected Indian Murder-for-Hire Plot on U.S. Soil Was Foiled
description: After a murder in Canada, a sting operation, prompted by an explosive tip through an unexpected channel, rushed to prevent another killing.
content: It was a mild Sunday evening in Surrey, a city near Vancouver, British Columbia, and Hardeep Singh Nijjar was ready to drive home after spending the day at his Sikh temple. He had told a friend that he thought he was being followed, but that night, he was just eager to celebrate Father’s Day with his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Atef Abu Saif
title: ‘I Want to Be Awake When I Die’
description: A Palestinian describes the tense journey through Gaza to bring his 15-year-old son to safety.
content: Atef Abu Saif was visiting family members in Gaza with his 15-year-old son, Yasser, before Oct. 7 and has kept a diary of the war since it began. Here is his entry for Nov. 21, the day he decided to leave the Jabaliya neighborhood in the north of the territory for southern Gaza, en route to the Rafah crossing into Egypt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: A C.E.O. Who Resigned in Scandal Now Wants More Money
description: Timothy J. Sloan was criticized for failing to clean up Wells Fargo’s troubled culture when he headed the bank. He says in a suit that he’s owed at least an additional $34 million.
content: As chief executive of Wells Fargo, Timothy J. Sloan failed to clean up a string of scandals that shook the bank and abruptly stepped down amid widespread criticism more than four years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: McCarthy, Laboring to Adjust to Life After the Speakership, Eyes Exiting Congress
description: The California Republican is still angry at his ouster and has struggled to acclimate. His colleagues expect him to retire, but he has taken his time deciding.
content: At an emotional evening news conference immediately after he was removed as speaker of the House, Representative Kevin McCarthy gave an inconclusive answer about whether he would remain in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Stop Whining, Mr. Santos. You Got a Fair Shake.
description: George Santos met a clear bar.
content: Before we wallow in the downfall of George Santos, allow me a toast of appreciation to the freshly defrocked lawmaker and his fellow lawmakers. It takes a lot to get booted from the House by one’s colleagues, but the New York Republican really applied himself. And while his 11 very weird months in office were a stain on American democracy, here’s hoping his departure serves to reassure a politically disillusioned nation that there is a level of deception, corruption and lunacy too extra even for Congress. It is a nice reminder that, on special occasions, most lawmakers still know how to do the right thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Being a Woman in Magic May be the Hardest Trick of All
description: Only about 8 percent of stage magicians are women. A new generation of performers wants to change that.
content: Though it was nearly five decades ago, Gay Blackstone can still vividly recall the first time she was sawed in half onstage. Her screams were an intended element of the illusion, but nerves and fear made them genuine that time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My Home Community Is Forcing Inspections. Can They Do That?
description: A homeowner’s association is a democracy, but living in one involves subjecting yourself to some intrusion. It’s all in the bylaws.
content: Q: In my townhome community on Long Island, the board is mandating that we submit to inspections of the exteriors and windows of our homes by an outside company. If the inspectors find deficiencies, we will be given time to correct them, or face escalating fines if we do not. Based on our experience, we expect that deficiencies will be highly discretionary. Residents own their homes and the small plots of land on which they sit, meaning we must grant the inspectors permission to enter our properties. Our governing documents already provide a mechanism to deal with obvious signs of neglect in isolated cases, but not these mass forced inspections. We keep our homes in generally excellent shape. Must we comply, and is this even legal in New York?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: O’Connor’s Most Vital Work Was After She Stepped Down
description: Justice O’Connor devoted her life after the court to fighting for an independent judiciary free of politics.
content: You can tell a lot about a person by what he or she regrets. This holds especially for Supreme Court justices, whose decisions can, with a single vote, upend individual lives and alter the course of history. Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. said he probably made a mistake in upholding a law criminalizing gay sex; Justice Harry Blackmun was sorry he ever voted to impose the death penalty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Tracing the Deep Roots of Ireland’s Support for Palestinians
description: In a country with its own history of a seemingly intractable conflict, the majority of people in Ireland are sympathetic to Palestinian civilians, while also condemning the Hamas attacks of Oct. 7.
content: Under the light drizzle of a Tuesday morning last month, Ríonach Ní Néill and a group of friends set up a small platform in front of the United States Embassy in Dublin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: When a Princess Runs the Ball and Rescues a Timid Boy
description: For the Scottish Ballet production of Cinderella, titled “Cinders!,” some performances flip the traditional gender roles. The dancers “were all kind of like: ‘OK. How does that work?’”
content: At a recent rehearsal of the Scottish Ballet, Marge Hendrick did something unusual for a ballerina. Running through a scene from “Cinders!,” a gender-bending new version of “Cinderella,” she grazed her partner Evan Loudon’s chin reassuringly as he looked down, unsure of himself. Then, Hendrick extended a hand to Loudon and paraded him around her, welcoming him to her world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Virshup
title: Who Needs an Airport Lounge When You’ve Got a Hot Spring?
description: What surprising amenities have you encountered at the terminal? Let us know.
content: At the end of my recent trip to Japan, I found myself at Haneda Airport in Tokyo with an hour or so to kill. So I went to the onsen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson and Desiree Rios
title: Desperate Families Search for Affordable Home Care
description: Facing a severe shortage of aides and high costs, people trying to keep aging loved ones at home often cobble together a patchwork of family and friends to help.
content: It’s a good day when Frank Lee, a retired chef, can slip out to the hardware store, fairly confident that his wife, Robin, is in the hands of reliable help. He spends nearly every hour of every day anxiously overseeing her care at their home on the Isle of Palms, a barrier island near Charleston, S.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: 10 Works and Performances That Helped Me Make Sense of 2023
description: Global conflict and personal loss encouraged our critic to seek out art that gave her a better understanding of grief and healing.
content: “I hope you don’t mind if we carry on,” Juicy says at the end of “Fat Ham.” The other characters in the play then begin cleaning and clearing the stage, an act that affirms Juicy’s proposition and, in this work inspired by Shakespeare’s most famous tragedy, suggests that there might be a way for them to work through their shared trauma together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: How American Evangelicalism Became ‘Mister Rogers With a Blowtorch’
description: In his new book, “The Kingdom, the Power, and the Glory,” the journalist Tim Alberta subjects his faith’s embrace of right-wing extremism to critical scrutiny.
content: What would Jesus do? It’s a question that the political journalist Tim Alberta takes seriously in his brave and absorbing new book, “The Kingdom, the Power, and the Glory,” pressing the evangelicals he meets to answer a version of it — even if a number of them clearly do not want to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: He Won Election to Canada’s Parliament. Did China Help?
description: A Canadian rapporteur said there was “well-grounded suspicion” that Han Dong, a member of Parliament from Toronto, may have benefited from support from the Chinese Consulate.
content: The newcomer landed in a district of northern Toronto and announced his bid for Canada’s Parliament. Though few knew him, an important factor helped offset his lack of name recognition — the backing of prominent local Chinese-Canadians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Emily Cochrane and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: In and Out of the Courtroom, O’Connor Inspired a Generation of Women
description: The Supreme Court justice, who died at 93 on Friday, made a series of influential rulings and inspired women across a range of fields as she cemented her legacy.
content: When Laney Serface was a young girl growing up in Northern California, she pinned a news article about Sandra Day O’Connor among the ephemera of theater tickets and photographs on her bulletin board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Berzon and Nick Corasaniti
title: Georgia County Signs Up to Use Voter Database Backed by Election Deniers
description: The decision ignores warnings from voting rights groups and some election experts.
content: A suburban county in Georgia agreed on Friday to use a new voter information database endorsed by the election denial movement, a move that defied warnings from voting rights groups, election security experts and state election officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada Fast-Tracks 10.4 Billion Dollar Military Purchase
description: To avoid a seemingly endless process, the government takes some political heat.
content: By Canadian standards, the 10.4 billion Canadian dollar military purchase announced this week moved at light speed, possibly within as little as nine months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Before You Buy a Christmas Tree, Can These Converts Sell You on a Fake?
description: The popularity of faux firs is soaring as the look becomes more convincing. But it isn’t necessarily good news for the environment.
content: Last year Charlene Truong Launer, a social media content creator, bought a real Christmas tree from a seller on a sidewalk in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Federal Judge Rejects Trump’s Immunity Claims in Election Case
description: The ruling is likely to spark a series of appeals that the former president’s lawyers hope will push the trial on election interference charges past the 2024 election.
content: A federal judge on Friday rejected claims by former President Donald J. Trump that he enjoyed absolute immunity from criminal charges accusing him of seeking to reverse the 2020 election, slapping down his argument that the indictment should be tossed out because it was based on actions he took while he was in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pascale Bonnefoy
title: Ex-Chilean Army Officer Is Expelled From U.S. to Face Charges in Singer’s Killing
description: Pedro Barrientos, 74, was charged in the kidnapping, torture and killing of the popular folk singer Víctor Jara days after the 1973 military coup that deposed President Salvador Allende.
content: A former Chilean Army officer has been deported from Florida to Chile to face charges in the kidnapping and killing of a popular folk singer and a prison director days after the 1973 military coup that deposed President Salvador Allende.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Two Books to Keep You Company While You Wait
description: Molly recommends a 19th-century “Dumb and Dumber” and a collection of essays about the weirder corners of the business world.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Why Don’t We Dance More?
description: Dancing offers an opportunity to use our bodies for something beyond mere practicality.
content: Remember Snowball, the sulphur-crested cockatoo whose fancy footwork to the Backstreet Boys’ “Everybody (Backstreet’s Back)” brought him viral fame in 2007? I recently rewatched the video, and it holds up. Here is this bird, perched on the back of a chair. As the song opens, he appears to be sketching out his moves, getting a feel for the song. When the chorus arrives, he shrieks and grooves, he high-kicks and head-bangs, settling into his rhythm, possessed by the beat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis Couldn’t Travel to the U.N. Climate Summit, but His Voice Did
description: A Vatican envoy delivered remarks in which Francis asked world leaders whether they would opt for “a culture of life or a culture of death.”
content: Pope Francis, who reluctantly canceled his trip to the annual United Nations climate summit in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, because of a lung infection, sought on Saturday to lend his voice to the world’s destitute facing the brunt of climate disruption.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Frustrations of Dating for Both Women and Men
description: Readers discuss a guest essay from a woman’s perspective about why more people aren’t getting married.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How Married Indie Pop Musicians Spend Their Sundays
description: Ian Devaney and Aidan Noell are two-thirds of Nation of Language, a synth pop band.
content: Ian Devaney and Aidan Noell, the married couple behind the indie pop trio Nation of Language, have been on a roll since they asked friends and family to fund their debut record in 2018 in lieu of wedding gifts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: Powerful Earthquake Strikes Eastern Philippines but Tsunami Fears Abate
description: The authorities in Japan and the Philippines lifted tsunami warnings in coastal regions after ordering evacuations. Power failures near the epicenter were reported.
content: A 7.6-magnitude earthquake struck the eastern parts of the Philippines on Saturday, leading to tsunami warnings across the region and as far as the southern part of Japan, nearly 2,000 miles away that were later lifted, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: The Cavalry Is Not Coming
description: When you realize help is not on the way, what do you do?
content: When you realize that help is not on the way, what do you do next?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Takes Fight for Second Place to Nikki Haley’s Home State
description: After ignoring each other for much of the campaign, the two candidates now engage in near-daily attacks and have sparred with increasing intensity on the debate stage.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Friday swept through South Carolina, his rival Nikki Haley’s backyard, seeking to blunt the rise of the state’s former governor in the Republican primary while capitalizing on his slugfest with the Democratic governor of California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Israelis Are Angry at Netanyahu, but Chances of His Ouster Are Slim
description: Many hold Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu responsible for his government’s failure to prevent the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas. His legacy could be determined by his actions in the coming days.
content: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister, has weathered many controversies, including accusations of corruption and allegations this year that a contentious overhaul of the country’s judiciary was a poorly disguised power grab.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Vivienne Walt
title: The Financial Paradox Blocking Efforts to Fight Climate Change
description: Finding money for fossil fuel plants is much easier than financing clean energy projects, especially in developing countries.
content: The annual United Nations climate change conference is underway in Dubai, and swirling around the COP28 negotiations is a complex, acrimonious, international fight over money:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Best Video Games of 2023
description: There was an embarrassment of riches from legacy role-playing franchises, beloved horror series and innovative newcomers.
content: The return of beloved characters along with ambitious new titles turned this year into one of the video game industry’s best, leaving players with an embarrassment of riches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: The Best Thrillers of 2023
description: They include an espionage caper, the tale of a murderous librarian and a high-stakes adventure that takes place inside the various stomachs of a whale.
content: This year’s best thrillers come in various shades of suspense, dread and wonder. But each leads the reader down a twisty path toward an unknown destination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle and Sarah Bahr
title: Emma Stone, Bowen Yang and Cynthia Erivo Partied in New York This Week
description: “Saturday Night Live” cast members attended the American Museum of Natural History gala, and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater celebrated its 65th anniversary season.
content: “I really want to be friends with a whale,” Mikey Day, the “Saturday Night Live” cast member, said this week as he stood inside the American Museum of Natural History and discussed his favorite displays. “They just look so magical.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Steel and Sydney Ember
title: Drunk and Asleep on the Job: Air Traffic Controllers Pushed to the Brink
description: A nationwide shortage of controllers has resulted in an exhausted and demoralized work force that is increasingly prone to making dangerous mistakes.
content: One air traffic controller went into work drunk this summer and joked about “making big money buzzed.” Another routinely smoked marijuana during breaks. A third employee threatened violence and then “aggressively pushed” a colleague who was directing airplanes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
title: Intelligence Errors Prompt Scrutiny of Israeli Generals, but Little Backlash
description: The Israeli media and The New York Times published damaging revelations suggesting that senior officers had ignored or dismissed intelligence reports about the likelihood of a major Hamas attack.
content: Israel’s military leadership faced heightened public scrutiny this week after a string of damaging revelations in the Israeli media and The New York Times suggested that senior officers had ignored or dismissed intelligence reports about the likelihood of a major Hamas attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hikari Hida
title: Unusual Names Can Complicate Life in Japan. Now Parents Are Being Reined In.
description: As such names have increased, so has media attention to cases of people unhappy with them. But critics say new rules may infringe on the right to be creative.
content: Growing up, all Yuni Matsumoto wanted was to fit in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Carmen Abd Ali
title: After Watching 10 Migrants Die at Sea, He Now Pleads: ‘Stay’
description: Witness to a tragedy on a boat to Spain, Moustapha Diouf has made it his mission to persuade young people not to emigrate from Senegal, but even he concedes that it’s getting harder to make his case.
content: Crowded together with 90 other migrants on a rickety fishing vessel bound for Spain, Moustapha Diouf watched 10 of them die, one by one, from heat and exhaustion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: John Nichols, Author of ‘The Milagro Beanfield War,’ Dies at 83
description: After decamping from New York to New Mexico, he wrote what was, for a time, among the most widely read novels about Latinos.
content: John Nichols, a New York City transplant to New Mexico whose exuberant novels, notably “The Milagro Beanfield War,” transformed him from an urban gringo into a local idol, died on Monday at his home in Taos. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Harris Says U.S. Strongly Opposes ‘Forced Relocation of Palestinians From Gaza’
description: The vice president’s statement came after a daylong meeting with Arab leaders in Dubai, where she was attending the U.N. climate summit.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris said on Saturday that the United States fiercely opposes forcibly relocating Gaza residents outside the enclave as Israel resumes its bombardment of Hamas terrorists, or in the days and weeks after the war eventually ends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Sam Altman, Sugarcoating the Apocalypse
description: Was the shake-up at OpenAI a farce or a tragedy?
content: My favorite “Twilight Zone” episode is the one where aliens land and, in a sign of their peaceful intentions, give world leaders a book. Government cryptographers work to translate the alien language. They decipher the title — “To Serve Man” — and that’s reassuring, so interplanetary shuttles are set up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Rasta Pasta, Brawny Veggies and All the Cookies
description: With Thai tea tres leches cake for good (holiday) measure.
content: The counter is stacked with blocks of softening butter, there’s three different kinds of sugar in the pantry and every kitchen surface is covered in a dusting of flour. All of which can only mean: Cookie Week is here!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé’ Review: Peak Performance
description: The concert film offers a comprehensive look at a world-conquering tour and rare insight into the process of one of the world’s biggest stars.
content: Of all the absurdities in “Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé,” the one that takes the cake comes in the homestretch, long after the film’s revealed itself to be both a face-warping concert movie and a moving, unexpectedly transparent feat of self-portraiture, after the screen’s gone black and the speakers silent during her performance of “Alien Superstar” (which happened for about 10 minutes on the tour’s Phoenix stop) and the placid voices at “Renaissance” mission control sound concerned, after we’ve beheld one costuming outrage chase another, after we’ve witnessed technicians inform her that something’s impossible and she informs them that she’s looked the problem up and that, indeed, it is possible. (“Eventually, they realize this bitch will not give up,” she says, backstage, to the camera.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Miller
title: When You Call Social Security, Expect to Wait Even Longer
description: The Social Security Administration’s staffing and customer service issues have been mounting, and budget disputes in Congress could make them worse.
content: Few government agencies touch the lives of more Americans than the Social Security Administration — the agency pays $1.4 trillion in benefits to more than 71 million people every year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: A Guide to N.Y.C. Holiday Events: Live Music, Theater, Lights and More
description: “The Nutcracker,” ice skating, menorah lighting, and Big Band carols at Lincoln Center: Here are some of our favorite things to do this season.
content: The holiday season has arrived in New York City, ushering in a host of performances and events, from modern retellings of “The Nutcracker” to holiday-themed jazz shows at Lincoln Center and outdoor train displays at the New York Botanical Garden. Here’s a list of shows and events to attend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: NOTE: The previous bug that omitted the HA word from today’s Spelling Bee has been resolved. Today’s Spelling Bee can be solved with 249 points and an HA word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla and Sinna Nasseri
title: The Plan to Save a California Island? Shoot All of the Deer.
description: For decades, nonnative animals have ravaged the rare habitat on Catalina. The proposed solution has infuriated local residents and animal lovers.
content: Santa Catalina Island is the crown jewel of the Channel Islands, an archipelago off the coast of Southern California that is so biodiverse it is often called “North America’s Galápagos.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: 22 Countries Pledge to Triple Nuclear Capacity in Push to Cut Fossil Fuels
description: The group, including Britain, France and the United States, said the agreement was critical to meeting nations’ climate commitments.
content: The United States and 21 other countries pledged on Saturday at the United Nations climate summit in Dubai to triple nuclear energy capacity by 2050, saying the revival of nuclear power was critical for cutting carbon emissions to near zero in the coming decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Lessons From Kissinger’s Triumphs and Catastrophes
description: And how we can apply them to China and Gaza today.
content: Henry Kissinger was the wisest of American foreign policy leaders and the most oblivious, the most farsighted and the most myopic, the one with the greatest legacy — and the one we should most study to learn what not to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Is South Korea Disappearing?
description: What a dramatic birth dearth portends for Koreans and the world.
content: For some time now, South Korea has been a striking case study in the depopulation problem that hangs over the developed world. Almost all rich countries have seen their birthrates settle below replacement level, but usually that means somewhere in the neighborhood of 1.5 children per woman. For instance in 2021 the United States stood at 1.7, France at 1.8, Italy at 1.3 and Canada at 1.4.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Santos Expelled as House Issues Historic Rebuke
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 2, 2023.
content: “To hell with this place.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Rawan Sheikh Ahmad and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel Orders Evacuations Amid ‘Intense’ Attacks on Southern Gaza
description: Beleaguered Gazans, having fled the territory’s north, emerged from a night of bombardment wondering where to go next for safety.
content: The Israeli military heavily bombarded southern Gaza on Saturday and ordered residents of several Palestinian border towns in the area to leave their homes, appearing to set the stage for a ground invasion in the south as hostilities resumed after the collapse of a weeklong truce with Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu, Ana Ley, Stephen Castle and Christina Anderson
title: Congestion Pricing’s Impact on New York? These 3 Cities Offer a Glimpse.
description: New York City is on the verge of becoming the first U.S. city to follow London, Stockholm and Singapore in trying to cut traffic by charging some drivers a fee.
content: New York is on the verge of becoming the first U.S. city to charge drivers for entering its busiest areas, but it is following three cities overseas where such tolling systems have become a way of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Ben Hubbard and Victoria Kim
title: Southern Gaza girds for the war’s next phase.
description: Gazans were bracing for expanded hostilities on Saturday, a day after the truce between Israel and Hamas ended, as Israel began turning its focus on southern Gaza for the war’s next phase and as the flow of vital supplies of food, water and medicine again slowed to a trickle.
content: Gazans were bracing for expanded hostilities on Saturday, a day after the truce between Israel and Hamas ended, as Israel began turning its focus on southern Gaza for the war’s next phase and as the flow of vital supplies of food, water and medicine again slowed to a trickle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Gambling, Risky Pranks and Lucrative Contracts: Inside the Streaming Site Kick
description: The Twitch competitor has doled out generous deals to content creators. It has also faced criticism for its lax moderation and embrace of online gambling.
content: One day this summer, the internet personality Adin Ross switched on his camera and started broadcasting himself live to thousands of fans, sipping a Yerba Mate drink and nodding along to Lil Uzi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: What to Know About Home Care Services
description: Finding an aide to help an older person stay at home safely takes work. Here’s a guide.
content: Most older Americans want to live at home as long as they can, but finding and affording the help they need often isn’t easy. There are severe shortages of home health aides in many parts of the country. Hiring them is costly. And most middle-class people will have to pay for home care themselves if they will need it for the long haul. Here’s a guide to locating home care for an older person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Grace Ashford and Michael Gold
title: What’s Next for George Santos? Court Dates and, Maybe, Reality TV.
description: The New York Republican suggested that his future might include a memoir or a reality television show, not to mention the looming criminal trial in federal court.
content: The expulsion of George Santos from the House on Friday, after a year shaped by audacious lies and outright frauds, ended his 11-month congressional tenure. But as he stormed off Capitol Hill, Mr. Santos made abundantly clear that he had no intention of returning to obscurity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Mica Ertegun, Glamorous Interior Designer and Philanthropist, Dies at 97
description: She and her longtime husband, the music magnate Ahmet Ertegun, were once called “the virtual definition of sophistication.”
content: Mica Ertegun, the New York doyenne of interior design who fled from Communism in postwar Romania, ran a chicken farm in Canada, married a legend of American pop music, and for 50 years dazzled her patrons with stylish décor, died on Saturday morning at her home in Southampton, N.Y., on Long Island. She was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Susan Sarandon Apologizes for Comment About Jews at Rally
description: The Oscar-winning actress said she now regrets “diminishing” the long history of antisemitism in remarks at the rally, which led her agents to part ways with her.
content: The Academy Award-winning actress Susan Sarandon apologized Friday for saying at a pro-Palestinian rally last month that people feeling afraid of being Jewish right now were “getting a taste of what it feels like to be a Muslim in this country, so often subjected to violence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Beyoncé the Auteur Takes Center Stage in ‘Renaissance’
description: She is essentially one on the new film, but she has also demonstrated throughout her career just who is in charge of her art.
content: “I’m excited for people to see the show,” Beyoncé says early in “Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé,” based on her recent world tour and seventh studio album. “But I’m really excited for everyone to see the process.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raul A. Reyes
title: I Survived ‘Guiding Light’
description: The long-running CBS soap opera had plenty of drama, onstage and off. A former cast member looks back on its last days.
content: Deep inside the CBS Broadcast Center in Midtown Manhattan, I stood in a corridor observing a melee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Freestyling
description: Tracy Bennett whips up a Sunday themeless with teeth!
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Will Shortz, in his print introduction to this grid, writes: “Tracy Bennett is a digital puzzles editor for The Times. She manages Wordle and helps with the Crossword. In this themeless puzzle, she took a bold grid pattern with lots of white squares and in each corner positioned a marquee answer — ‘something new or that had an appealing sound or cluing potential.’ Then she built out from there.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Stuff in Microdots
description: Royce Ferguson’s Saturday puzzle takes us on an interesting trip.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the third Times crossword from Royce Ferguson — after a three-year hiatus — and his second Saturday grid. It’s stylish! There’s great cluing, a lot of snappy new entries and the puzzle’s arrangement uses long entries as links to connect its quadrants, which makes getting stranded a distinct probability. I got stuck a few times, but I can’t point to anything obscure or unfair, just the kind of subterfuge that makes for a good, chewy themeless challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Levitt and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: What the Scale of Displacement in Gaza Looks Like
description: Eighty percent of Gazans are displaced from their homes as Israel orders more evacuations. See where thousands have been sheltering amid the war’s destruction.
content: Eighty percent of Gazans are displaced from their homes as Israel orders more evacuations. See where thousands have been sheltering amid the war’s destruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis and Judson Jones
title: 2023 Hurricane Season Ends, Marked by Storms That ‘Really Rapidly Intensified’
description: There have been a combined 37 named storms this year in the Atlantic and Eastern Pacific basins. A high proportion of those quickly escalated.
content: There have been a combined 37 named storms this year in the Atlantic and Eastern Pacific basins. A high proportion of those quickly escalated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, John Keefe, Judson Jones and Bea Malsky
title: Map: 7.6-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes the Philippine Sea
description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
content: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
source.name: The New York Times
